steps.title: Clean the chives.
steps.content: Clean the chives. [1] X Research source Rinse them under cold running water and remove any dead or withered chives. Pat them dry with a clean towel or kitchen towel until all moisture is removed.

steps.title: Collect and bundle the chives.
steps.content: Collect and bundle the chives. Gather the chives into loose bundles that you can easily hold in one hand. Secure the stems with kitchen twine or a rubber band, ensuring that they stay together securely without crushing them. Trim off the excess bottom and top portions of any stems that stick out if you want the bundles to look even. If you are cutting the chives from a garden, trim them early in the morning after the dew has dried when they are the healthiest and full of flavor.

steps.title: Hang the bunches of chives upside down in a brown paper bag.
steps.content: Hang the bunches of chives upside down in a brown paper bag. Cut small holes or slits in the sides of the small paper bags to allow airflow. Gather the top of the bag together with string and hang the chives inside the bag from the top. The bag prevents dust from gathering on the chives and keeps sunlight from bleaching out their green color.

steps.title: Store the bags of chives in a cool, dry location.
steps.content: Store the bags of chives in a cool, dry location. Leave them for approximately two weeks until they are brittle to the touch. Check the chives every few days to ensure that no mold has developed on them.

steps.title: Crumble the chives.
steps.content: Crumble the chives. Remove the chives from the bags and bundles and place them on parchment paper or a cutting board. Gently crumble the chives with your hands or chop them with a knife into small pieces.

steps.title: Place the dried chives in an airtight container such as a glass mason jar and store out of direct sunlight.
steps.content: Place the dried chives in an airtight container such as a glass mason jar and store out of direct sunlight.

steps.title: Preheat the oven to the lowest temperature, ideally to 185˚ F (85˚ C) or lower.
steps.content: Preheat the oven to the lowest temperature, ideally to 185˚ F (85˚ C) or lower. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Cut the chives into 1/4” inches (0.
steps.content: Cut the chives into 1/4” inches (0. 6 cm) with a knife or kitchen scissors. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Spread the chives on a shallow baking sheet.
steps.content: Spread the chives on a shallow baking sheet. Line the baking sheet with parchment paper before spreading out the chives to keep them from scorching on the metal.

steps.title: Heat the tray of chives in the oven for one to two hours.
steps.content: Heat the tray of chives in the oven for one to two hours. Check the chives periodically to make sure they do not burn. Remove them when they crumble easily between your fingers.

steps.title: Gather up the parchment paper and funnel the chives into a glass jar with a tight fitting lid.
steps.content: Gather up the parchment paper and funnel the chives into a glass jar with a tight fitting lid. Seal the jar and store the chives in a cool location away from sunlight.

steps.content: Spread the chives evenly on the food dehydrator tray. Cover the chives with a screen (if included with the dehydrator) to prevent them from blowing around.
